results.title: Tales of Beatrix Potter
results.creator_credit: Reginald Mills, Richard Goodwin and EMI/Parlophone
results.brief_description: Dancers of the Royal Ballet perform classic stories from the tales of Beatrix Potter bringing to life many of her best-loved characters - Mrs Tiggy-Winkle, Pigling Bland, Squirrel Nutkin and many more. They were the tales we loved as children and still hold with great affection as adults. Brilliantly designed by Christine Edzard, and beautifully danced by some of the great names of the Royal Ballet. This is one of the most charming and ingenious ballet films of recent years.

results.title: Stickmen
results.creator_credit: Hamish Rothwell, Michelle Turner, Film 2, New Zealand Film Commission, New Zealand On Air and Stickfilms
results.brief_description: Sticks, or pool, means more than life to Jack (Robbie Magasiva), Wayne (Scott Wills) and Thomas (Paolo Rotondo) - it can even override sex. In fact, “pub pool is the perfect game…conflict, drama, thrill of the chase, strategy and a cliff-hanger ending”. What more could you want? As best mates, the trio spend most of their spare time hustling at Dave’s Bar for a bit of a laugh and some money on the side until one night they are asked to enter into a high stakes tournament run by the local crime boss “Daddy” (Enrico Mammarella). Their pool-playing lives suddenly changes - as the stakes get higher so trouble seems to follow and all three are faced with the prospect of doing what Daddy asks or else! But more than anything else, the “Stickmen” want to win. Humor, sex, violence, romance and pool blend together to make this a quirky and upbeat film in the tradition of “Lock stock and two smoking barrels” and also is director Hamish Rothwell’s first feature film. Cast includes Anne Nordhaus, Simone Xessell, John Leigh, Kirk Torrance, Luanne Gordon.

results.title: Spaceborne
results.brief_description: Rarely seen footage from NASA missions shows the excitement of man’s first ventures into space. The editing and music transform the images into an exciting visual experience. No spoken commentary.

results.title: Shanghai Express
results.creator_credit: Josef von Sternberg, Adolph Zukor and Paramount Pictures
results.brief_description: The lightweight plot - an evacuation by train from Peking to Shanghai - is merely the pretext for one of Sternberg’s most successful pieces of stylization, a fruitful collaboration with cinematographer Lee Garmes (and an uncredited James Wong Howe), and writer Jules Furthman. Dietrich plays Shanghai Lily, a ‘coaster’ (a woman who lives by her wits along the Chinese coast) whose scandalous lifestyle is summed up in the films now classic line, ‘It took more than one man to change my name to Shanghai Lily’. Clive Brook’s plays Dietrich’s love interest Captain Donald Harvey, a stuffy Englishman who knew Lily before her infamous lifestyle and is still hurting from her having previously run off on him. Sternberg uses the stop-start cadences of the narrative as a means to evoke the rhythm of the train, while functioning as a kind of time machine confronting the motley group with their pasts as it carries them to their respective fates. However Sternberg’s main point of interest is Dietrich whose status in the film takes on fetishistic proportions, while being gloriously framed and lit in every scene. Cast includes Anna May Wong, Louise Closser Hale, Eugene Pallette, Lawrence Grant. (Awards: Winner, Best Cinematography- Lee Garmes, Academy Awards, 1932)

constellations_other.name: Legacy of an icon: Anna May Wong
constellations_other.description: Wong Liu Tsong, known professionally as Anna May Wong, was a film star in the 1920s and 30s who made a career for herself despite racist stereotypes and vilification. Her legacy lives on as she is now being portrayed by contemporary actors on film and TV.

results.title: Scribbling kitten
results.brief_description: A kitten named Miaow draws on Mr Bear’s wall watched by two mice friends. When Miaow is finally caught he has to wash the drawings off the wall but when the two mice decide to interfere, the chase is on.

results.title: Ruby and Rata
results.creator_credit: Gaylene Preston, Robin Laing, New Zealand Film Commission and Preston-Laing Productions
results.brief_description: Comedy drama about the relationship between two New Zealand women who seemingly have absolutely nothing in common, apart from their fierce independence. Rata, is a single Maori mother in her twenties frauding the welfare system in order to get by. Ruby, is an elderly Pakeha, an intolerant, middle-class pensioner, who owns her own home in the Auckland suburbs. The two are thrown together when Ruby’s nephew rents her basement flat to Rata. When Ruby discovers that Rata is not the nice young single professional woman she imagined, but has a wild young son named Willie who sings in a rowdy band, she tries unsuccessfully to evict her. Yet their mutual hostility gradually wanes, largely due to the intervention of Willie, who strikes up an odd relationship with Ruby. Eventually the two women find common ground and pool their resources to survive. The film critiques the economic rationalism that took hold in New Zealand in the eighties, while celebrating the perseverance of ordinary people caught in an economic and social underclass. Cast includes Yvonne Lawley, Vanessa Rare, Simon Barnett and Lee Mete-Kingi.

results.title: Road to Nhill
results.creator_credit: Sue Brooks, Sue Maslin, Australian Film Commission and Gecko Films
results.brief_description: This affectionate observation of life in a small country town follows the events of a lazy summer’s afternoon in Pyramid Hill, Victoria. A car load of local lady bowlers flips over on the way home from a tournament. Confusion escalates as word about the accident spreads around the town. Husbands go astray searching for their wives; helpful passers-by take the women involved in the accident in all directions; the ambulance gets lost; and the local policeman misses the accident all together. The film is the first feature for the director/ producer/writer team after several years of documentaries and short films, many of them award-winning.

results.title: Quasi at the Quackadero
results.brief_description: Features Quasi, a science fiction boy who lives in a progressive household with his grown-up friend Anita and the little robot friend Rollo. Follows them on a day’s outing to Quackadero, the Coney Island of the future.

results.title: Playful Pluto
results.creator_credit: Joseph Schenck and Walt Disney Productions
results.brief_description: Animated cartoon starring Mickey Mouse and Pluto. Begins with Mickey raking up leaves in his garden and playful Pluto trying his best to be helpful but instead creating total mayhem, going from one catastrophe to another.

results.title: Once were warriors (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Lee Tamahori, Robin Scholes, Avalon Studios, Communicado, New Zealand Film Commission and New Zealand On Air
results.brief_description: Based on Alan Duff’s controversial best seller, “Once Were Warriors” is an intense and powerful film that leaves audiences stunned with its uncompromising insight into the strength of Maori culture in the face of degrading urban ghettos and devastating family violence. Jake (Temuera Morrison) and Beth (Rena Owen) have been married 18 years and she still finds him irresistible. Jake is a muscular, handsome man who exudes an explosive sexual energy but spends most of the time at the pub, often proving his masculinity with his fists and regularly exploding into rages that leave terrible scars on Beth and his family.
